none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from E. B. Cushing, March 27, 1891
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from E. B. Cushing, March 27, 1891
Box 2 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 2 Folder 6 Louis L. McInnis Papers
Galveston, Harrisburg & San Antonio Railway Co.

en: E. B. Cushing writes to Louis L. McInnis on March 27, 1891, from Houston regarding a petition campaign aimed at influencing the Texas Governor. Cushing proposes organizing typewritten petitions to be circulated among military academy alumni in major Texas cities and presented by sympathetic legislators. He notes potential obstacles including his own political opposition to Captain Hatcheson but commits to leveraging his connections with Major Looscan and other influential former cadets to advance the cause.

body.value:
[Header]

G. H.) M. 18½.
GALVESTON, HARRISBURG & SAN ANTONIO RAILWAY CO.
TEXAS & NEW ORLEANS RAILROAD CO.

Subject......................................................
Resident Engineer
Office of......................................................

To...................................................... HOUSTON March 27 1891

[Body]

My dear Sir:-
Your favor 21st reached me to day.
I will gladly do anything in my power
to assist you – and I believe that you
Can Count on the friendly assistance of
a large number of the old Cadets.
My acquaintance and influence – if I have
any influence – would be confined to
those of the Cadets who attended
School prior to 1879. but these being now
in business life might have more
weight = My idea would be to have
type written petitions made and sent to
some leading Cadets in all the large Towns
Say Houston – Galveston. Ft Worth – Austin – Dallas
San Antonio Sherman Tyler &c &c and have
these returned when signed to me or some
other party and by him presented to the
Governor. There will be no trouble in obtaining
the signatures of all the “old boys” in this
town in a short while. There are four of
the boys now in the Legislature towit:
Rogan – King – Shaw & Clegg. and I
think it would be a good idea to have
one of them present the petitions – Say Rogan – whom
I think is friendly is he not?

[Footer]

2

**Transcriptionist's Internal Thought Process: A Deep Dive** Okay, here's the deal. I'm looking at this request, and my brain immediately snaps into "transcriptionist mode." I've got to extract the information from this image, ensuring accuracy and adhering to a very specific set of guidelines. It's like a code I have to execute, and here's how I break it down: First, I need to understand the mission. The parameters are clear: *transcribe*, keeping the original mechanics (spelling, capitalization, punctuation), and preserving the layout as best as possible. The client wants me to interpret the handwriting, not change it. This means I'm not correcting grammar or cleaning up any perceived errors. I need to spot and tag any structural elements. And of course, I must utilize only the permitted HTML tags. I must produce nothing but the text. I need to view the image as if I were there. It looks like a letter, likely a business communication given the railway company letterhead. There's a form number at the top left. The railway company name and the usual "To," "Subject," and "Office of" fields, all typical. I see a stamped "Resident Engineer" and what looks like a date. I will use the available information to produce the output. I'm analyzing the handwriting style – cursive, a little loopy, and unmistakably late 19th-century. The writing flows continuously; this will require careful attention to line breaks and paragraph structure. The content seems to revolve around helping someone, perhaps a former cadet, with a petition or some kind of influence campaign. The writer is mentioning specific towns in Texas and names of people in the legislature. Now, step-by-step, I will construct the transcription. I'm going to take the elements and then build it into the correct format. * Form number: I will use `` for the form number. * Letterhead: I am going to organize and write all the header information correctly, but there are no visible tags. There is not a format for a header on the required tags list. * I transcribe the stamped text. * I see the date "March 27 1891". The 21st has superscript. * I recognize the salutation "My dear Sir:-". * I will note that in body paragraph 1 that "21st" uses a superscript for "st". * I interpret an unclear scribble "made [scribble] sent". I will transcribe that the word "and" is written over the word "out". I'll use "and" as it appears to be the final intent, but I'll make sure to note that the image has an original overwritten text. * I check for all the listed towns in Texas and note that this uses "&c &c". * The text is flowing, so I'm paying attention to the sentence structure as well. * There are four of the people present in the state legislature mentioned. * I will look at formatting: Using `

` and `
`. Then, I will note the Header section. The "Subject" is quite high. "Resident Engineer" is stamped. The "Resident Engineer" is faintly red. * Now I will review the transcription to the image to look for any mistakes. * I am now checking the final version: "towit" vs "to wit", "&c &c", Rogan, Clegg, type written, old boys, favor 21st, 1/2. * "towit" has a connection. * "&c &c" is standard. * I will write the names exactly as they are. * The "favor" uses superscript on the "21st" * I construct the output: * I will build the Header first. I must keep the layout of this section in mind, keeping these lines together. * The body flows, so I need to create the paragraphs. * The word "and" is written over. * The names are clear. * I review "made [scribble] sent". And write it as "made and sent". * The instructions list are correct. * I will write the Header: * `G. H.) M. 18½.` * GALVESTON, HARRISBURG & SAN ANTONIO RAILWAY CO. * TEXAS & NEW ORLEANS RAILROAD CO. * Subject...................................................... * Resident Engineer * Office of...................................................... * To...................................................... HOUSTON March 27

(G. H.) M. 18 1/2.
GALVESTON, HARRISBURG & SAN ANTONIO RAILWAY CO.
TEXAS & NEW ORLEANS RAILROAD CO.
[Margin: [1891, March 27]]
Subject ........................................................................
To J G M ........................................................................ Office of ........................................................................
........................................................................ 189

I do not think that this form of petition
unsupported would avail much but
if it can be backed with personal
letters from men in position it may
carry the point. I regret that
my political opposition to Capt Hatcheson
places me in bad light to approach
him on the subject but might do so
through others. I will however
see Major Looscan who is a close friend
of the Governor and see what he
can & will do. My business keeps me
away so much from home that I
cannot give the case the time which
one should who attempts to look
after it but will do the best I
can. I leave to night for El Paso
will be on the field for next two
weeks. Please write me your
views as fully as you can & let
me know who you consider one of your
Closest friends among the old boys
in the large cities. Pls look over
Inclosed sample which after writing strikes me
as somewhat weak - Return it with any remarks
Our correspondence will of course be strictly confidential

Yours truly
E. B. Cushing

**Okay, let's break down this transcription. It's time to pull up my sleeves and get to the core of this image. I am going to analyze this document and extract its information.** First, I see a handwritten letter on what looks like Galveston, Harrisburg & San Antonio Railway Co. and Texas & New Orleans Railroad Co. letterhead. There is a pencil annotation in the top right that looks like "[1891, March 27]", which should be recorded. The printed date is "189". The addressee appears to be "To J G M" followed by something illegible. It could be "Esq" or a flourish, but I should stick to the clear text and render as "To J G M [?]". The subject and office fields are blank. Next, it's time to tackle the body of the text. I will take this line by line: * **Header:** * `(G. H.) M. 18 1/2.` (Small print at the top) * `GALVESTON, HARRISBURG & SAN ANTONIO RAILWAY CO.` * `TEXAS & NEW ORLEANS RAILROAD CO.` * `Subject` ................................. * `To J G M` [?] ................................ Office of ................................. * ................................................ 189 * **Body Text:** * "I do not think that this form of petition" (I initially thought the handwriting was "donor", but the context is "do not", which is correct.) * "unsupported would avail much but" * "if it can be backed with personal" * "letters from men in position it may" * "carry the point. I regret that" * "my political opposition to Capt Hutcheson" (Or rather, the name "Hatcheson", given the handwriting) * "places me in bad light to approach" * "him on the subject but might do so" * "through others. I will however" * "see Major Looscan who is a close friend" * "of the Governor and see what he" * "can & will do. My business keeps me" * "away so much from home that I" * "cannot give the case the time which" * "one should who attempts to look" * "after it but will do the best I" * "can. I leave to night for El Paso" * "will be on the field for next two" * "weeks. Please write me your" * "views as fully as you can & let" * "me know who you consider ^one of^ your" * "Closest friends among the old boys" (I had to carefully look at that one; initially, it looked like "Clrest", but contextually, it is "Closest". The handwriting is messy, but it's "C" "l" "o" "s" "e" "s" "t") * "in the large cities. Pls look over" ("Pls" is the abbreviation, not "Ple".) * "Inclosed sample which after writing strikes me" (The word is "Inclosed," the older spelling of "Enclosed", though it looked a bit like "luclosed" in the handwriting) * "as somewhat weak - Return it with any remarks" (The word "Return" has an uppercase R. It's written as two words.) * "Our correspondence will of course be strictly confidential" * **Signature:** * "Yours truly" * "E. B. Cushing" I am going to use HTML and structure it logically: `

` for paragraphs, `` or `` for smaller header text, and `
` for line breaks. I should transcribe the pencil date. I'm going to preserve the original spelling, punctuation, capitalization, and line breaks. So, let's put it all together to create an accurate and structured transcription of this letter.
